Key Arguments: There is no absolute standard for truth, making it dangerous for any authority to determine what is correct.
Scientific claims are subject to change, indicating that truth is not fixed.
The terms misinformation and disinformation are misleading and suggest an entity can determine truth.
Free speech, even if it includes false or unpleasant information, is safer than censorship.
Legislation to curb misinformation could lead to authoritarianism.
Free market solutions and public discussions are better alternatives to legislation.
Main Themes: Criticism of the terms misinformation and disinformation
Notable Quotes: The reason for free speech is that there is no absolute standard for truth or correct information known to humankind.
The alternative is establishing a ministry of truth and censorship, a key feature of authoritarian regimes.
Any attempt to filter or fine-tune the right to free speech via legislation and punishments will likely backfire.
